intro: Panicum warmingii, commonly known as the Warming grass, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the grass family, Poaceae, and is characterized by its slender, erect stems and fine, thread-like leaves. The plant produces small, spike-like inflorescences that bear numerous tiny flowers, which are typically green to brown in color. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in wetlands, marshes, and along the edges of ponds. Due to its ecological importance and ornamental value, it is sometimes cultivated in wetland restoration projects.
